hedline.hl1: A Family Gallery, Claws and All

abstract.p: Artist Barbara Page is painting series of 544 portraits of fossils, representing 500 milllion years of evolution; photos; works will be installed in Museum of the Earth in Ithaca, New York, which is to open in 2002 (S)

block.p: At the Museum of the Earth, scheduled to open in Ithaca, N.Y., in 2002, visitors will walk back into the past.

Barbara Page, a Trumansburg, N.Y., artist, is painting a series of 544 portraits of fossils, representing half a billion years of evolution. Beginning with the present day, each succeeding panel along a ramp leading into the museum will represent a one-million-year step back in time, through the age of mammals to the time of dinosaurs and earlier, ending with the appearance of the first multicellular animals about 544 million years ago.

Barbara Page, a Trumansburg, N.Y., artist, is painting a series of 544 portraits of fossils, representing half a billion years of evolution. Beginning with the present day, each succeeding panel along a ramp leading into the museum will represent a one-million-year step back in time, through the age of mammals to the time of dinosaurs and earlier, ending with the appearance of the first multicellular animals about 544 million years ago.
Plants and animals, numbering about 1,000, are all depicted life-size in the panels. For creatures too large to fit in the one-foot-square panel, the artist included pieces like a skull or a claw.
